Hi, Destin. I THINK I have an answer for the thermal interactions... Peltier junctions. If current flows one direction the hot and cold sides will be one way. Reverse the current, and they flip over! Thus, you'd have one side of the junction touching your hand, and the other some kind of heat sink. This is where just a steady flow of water would be sufficient... you don't have the lag of the flow, or lags in changing the temperature, etc... the Peltier junction is against your hand, and can change very quickly, depending on the current flow and direction. By changing the "attack/decay/sustain/release" of the current, they can make the temperature change quickly, slowly, etc, and adjust your perception. NOTE: I have NO CONNECTION AT ALL with the folks at HAPTX, this is just MY THEORY about how this works... based on the limited information given here, and my own GEEK factor. :) Just FYI, I absolutely LOVED this video and the one before it... these are AMAZING and are my favorite of all the "Smarter Every Day" vids. :) God bless!!

I honestly first thought about the electrical process auto makers use to heat and cool seats in vehicles. Take my dads Ram 1500, he got all the bells and whistles. This was the first vehicle I had ever ridden in that had not just heated seats, because thats been around for a long time. But also cooling function as well. I had gone to school to auto and Diesel training. I am Ford certified. But I never worked on fords. I worked on Cummins engines and freightliner trucks. My dads truck has cooling option for his seats and when you hit the button its pretty quick about removing the heat from my seat. You do feel the difference quickly. And its all done by how they direct electricity through these modules in the seats. If they run electricity one way through it the seats will heat up. If they run electricity the other way the seats will cool. I don't remember the exact names and details. But I at least remember this much. So that's why I first thought they might be using a similar system. But to my knowledge the modules are big enough to hold in one hand. But its the special material or alloy they use to do the heating and cooling thats important. So I guess they could come up with a way to make it fit in a glove.

You cannot feel the actual temperature of any object, not just metal. You can only somewhat reliably tell if it is colder or hotter than the part of your own tissue that comes in contact with it.

I find it interesting that they are still taking a George Jetson approach on this.  By that I mean taking a real life process and just mechanizing it.  Such as when Jane wanted a new knit sweater, a robot with six arms comes out and knits a new sweater.  It isn't the future as much as the present on steroids.  Doing it faster vs doing it completely different.  There is nothing wrong with the George Jetson approach.  It is the first step towards thinking about how to change from mimicking reality to directly tricking your brain.  Take something simple like VR goggles.  They shoot light directly into your eye and you are seeing something vs. tapping into your optic nerve and tricking you into thinking you are seeing something kind of like Geordi on StarTrek.  With ths haptic glove, if you took the approach of tapping into the nerve bundle in your arm and trick that into thinking you are feeling pressure, temperature, location, then you open the world to totally making someone think they are experiencing reality.  Cool stuff non-the-less.

At a good guess, the temperature feedback would be a tile array of small pelitiers, you dont need to push much energy, the small mass will allow quick response, and by keeping them small, you can overcome the fragility of it, equally i believe the 2 point for temperature is much wider, like 1.5cm on a finger, and 3cm on the palm.

As for the pnuematics, the length of hose they chose to demo with makes me think all feeds go back to the box, (really thick control cable), where the valving sits, its likely a bank of 3 way micro solenoids activing as a selecting matrix, hooked up to supply and drain, (they make them both stupidly small and PCB mountable.)

To fill a given sensor you pulse its selection solenoid either positive to fill, or negative to drain, or left alone to maintain with minimal leakage, relying on timing for the amount. I would suspect they also would have some manner of self referencing routine where when sensors are not in use, every now and then pulse them to drain to make sure they are not inflated.

Same goes for the force feedback, if you have ever fought a bus or trains pnuematic door, it gives a very nice exponential resistance curve, the more you fight it, the more resistance it applies, maintaining the illusion that it is solid and rigid. these however need finer feedback of finger and palm curl to properly maintain it, as you will instinctivly change the amount of force you apply. again never measuring the pressure, just corrective pulses.

Using hot and cold fluid in the glove for temperature seems unrealistic. However a method such as thermoelectric cooling/heating might is something I think is likely to be used in the future. Check out this link https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermoelectric_cooling

Amazing stuff!! I am (or was) a fellow VR peripheral developer. Our project didn't end up coming to fruition but I wish you guys (haptx) the best of luck on your journey! What a lot of people don't realize is how hard it is to make an idea come to life. The idea/invention is the easy part. Actually making it work, R&D, ordering/creating parts that don't even exist yet. Finding out that you figured out how to design a part but you have no idea how it can physically be created or who can manufacture it. Finding suppliers to make these parts at a reasonable cost while still keeping confidentiality... Then you finally figure out the mechanics of the product. Now all you need is (literally) the worlds best software engineers to engineer something that has never been done before. They have to develop your proprietary software out of thin air to communicate with your proprietary device, neither of which has ever been done by mankind. Making sure it actually works on consumer platforms. Not only that, but doing it at a latency that was unheard of a year ago. Then calculating the magnetic pull of the Earth and every possible electronic device so it doesn't dirty the magnetic tracking on the controllers. Figuring out the equation, but finding out it might be too similar to someone like Sixenses (or whoever's) patent..  Realizing you now have to license part of an idea from a company, and now you have to work with them. Not even mentioning keeping the whole team motivated, getting funding, and sticking to a budget.  There are SO many factors to developing a peripheral and you guys are nailing every single one! I am SO happy that a team is working on such an advanced device! Most people put an old cell phone vibrator in a 3d printed sleeve, call it haptics and charge 500$.  Mark my words, your company will single-handedly advance VR technology 10-15 years ahead of everyone else. I don't even care how much your product costs at first. It's just the fact that the technology will be created!  Sure the big HMD companies would love to make haptic gloves. As much as they would love to create an amazing product, some of them are public companies not focused fully in VR. So they can't release the game breaking invention right away. They can just put capacitive sensors on a controller that will show simulated finger movement. Then the next year they add another little feature. Then the next year they might add individual rumble motors to at least 2 or 3 fingers. . Then here comes your company... BAM. Everybody better step up their game! I absolutely love FB/Oculus, Valve, and every one of their team members for everything they are doing for VR and bringing it to the masses, but I am really happy that there is a team like you out there grinding and pushing the peripheral market. It's companies like yours that change the world. It is so motivating that there are teams like yours that exist. Don't ever quit! //endrant

i would expect them to use thermo electric coolers. also known as peltier devices. electricity provided in one direction will give a rapid cooling effect on one side. if you swap the polarity it will rapidly heat up then cool on the other side.

using this method they could only provide a cooling effect for only a short time until the whole device becomes heat soaked. if a water cooling loop were added on the far side (side you do not contact) they would be able to maintain the effect as the water can be sent through a small radiator elsewhere to dissociate the extra heat as they are roughly 50% efficient. the efficacy is really a function of the temperature delta.

this is the same technology used in those charge your phone with fire products or the devices that precisely temperature control fiber optic lasers and high power LEDs. side note if you do not, the wavelength of light they emit will shift causing dispersion and increased thermal noise in fiber optic systems

So why pneumatic instead of hydraulic? You'd get faster response since fluids are basically incompressible.

Perhaps to be able to change temperature quickly they set two different fluid lines, hot/cold, like a faucet's plumbing, and just inject more of one to compensate the temperature difference as the other drains away.
Let me give an example of what I think:
You're feeling something hot (aka hot fluid is pumped to your hand), then in order to feel something cold quickly, more cold fluid is injected to compensate for the warm one still present as it drains away.
This would, I think, work quickly enough to trick your brain at a sudden change of surface, but would require a little downtime before being able to switch back (I'm talking about probably ~0.4s) as the drained/draining fluid needs to be replaced with reheated/refrigerated fluid.

With it using fluid (not to mention all those numatic lines) rather than completely electrical I foresee a huge challenge when they finally try and make it light weight and small enough to completely fit on the forearm or back of the hand. Hope they get that far and don't have to stop at only a sit down or tethered experience. I think they are using back up air tanks or storage at high pressures/low pressures to achieve the rise time on the bladders. The higher relative pressure would mitigate the response time, and they would only have to open and close the valves quickly (very quickly) to achieve specific pressures. Such as:
A 100 psi tank opens for a tenth of a second into a small 20psi canister, allowing for the canister to achieve 30psi. (not actual values, but just an example.) Then a low pressure or vacuum tank allows for the rapid evacuation back down to normal pressure.
Or, if its for a small period of time for a simple rapid touch, instead of allowing the bladders to fill up then release, they keep the out valve open and open the in valve for a short period of time, that would create a hair like or rapid touch example.

It would be the same for fluids. Hot and cold temperature fluids reside in a storage tank at high pressures. To achieve 90 degrees, they add certain amounts of each and blast them through the same tube to rapidly mix the two, achieving a precise temperature. (All other work is offsite in the calculations, the **easy part). You wouldn't want to pump directly to the gloves because you have to worry about (depending on the type of pump) spin up times or pulsing pressure.

I'm sure you already know this, but the sensation of "hot" is not actually it's own sensation, it's warm + cold sensations happening simultaneously.  You can simulate "hot" by setting your faucet to a light stream of slightly warm water, and having a cup of ice water.  Place your finger under the warm stream from the sink, and then pour the cold water right next to the warm water.  Right near the interface between the two, you will perceive "hot."  If done just right, you'll instinctively yank your hand away and feel like you've burnt your finger for about 10 minutes.  Great fun at parties.  I'm betting these guys must've dealt with that in some way, because it would be extremely easy to cause actual discomfort with high enough resolution cold and warm water cells in proximity.  I'd even go so far as to say that they probably have a proprietary "faux burning" simulation that they've used to trick coworkers.  If I worked there, I would've definitely done that.  :D

How do I love thee? Let me count the ways...

1.) I love the way you are so excited to learn. Your face lights up when you see something fascinating, and you immediately want to learn all about it. You don't take anything for granted.
2.) I love that you always do plenty of research on the subject, so you don't sound like a moron gleefully yelping over things he doesn't understand. Often you ask questions using words I never knew existed. You're the kind of inquisitor I want to be.
3.) I love the way you are always so upbeat. You see the bright side of everything, and focus on the positives, and you don't let the problems get you down.
4.) I love how deeply you can analyze a thing. You see features most people never notice. Often you see features even I don't notice.
5.) I love how you can make something we take for granted into something impressive, something worth studying. The world around me feels richer thanks to your videos.
6.) I love that you have a way with words. Where I often stutter and struggle to find the best word for something, and many others don't even know the big words, you have a large vocabulary and the skill to use it well.
7.) I love how you connect with your audience. You bridge the gap between the experts and us regular people. You make these things palatable for us to learn, and are able to translate the technical details into something we can all understand.

To me, you're up there with David Attenborough and Bill Nye. You're that amazing.

I'm excited about Ready Player One so I decided to do a deep dive into the science of virtual reality. This is the second part of the series. I haven't revealed what the next video is about... but it's super interesting and probably a bit unexpected.

There are tons of things I had never considered about how difficult it is to fool your brain into thinking it's touching something it's not. I think the most important technical issue to overcome is timing. Much like how your brain can understand hearing someone's voice AFTER seeing their lips move, but not the opposite... the lag time of the sense of touch is an important thing for your brain. Another thing I hadn't considered is the "rise time" that has to do with internal stresses in your fingers. If you conceptualize your fingers as water balloons around bones, you can understand how the internal pressure of your fingers rise the harder you press something. This type of information coupled with the "Sensory Homunculus" make for some incredibly fulfilling thought experiments.

The temperature question is something I'm particularly interested in. Using a colder fluid to model a room temperature fluid because of the heat transfer equation is a fascinating area of scientific problem solving. If you think it through, everything about this boils down to differential equations. How much heat is leaking out of the hand, and at what rate, through what contact area?
